tips.title: Water in the house is free
tips.description: In Paris, you don't need to pay for mineral water. Always order a **Carafe d'eau** (pitcher of water) in restaurants. It's the law: they must serve free tap water, which is drinkable and cold.

highlights.info: Pronounced 'caraf dô'. It's the glass jug with tap water.

tips.title: The Metro and the T+ Ticket
tips.description: Don't throw away your subway ticket until you leave the station! Inspection is frequent and the fine is high (generally €35 or more). Keep the validated ticket with you.

highlights.info: The little white ticket. Keep it until you pass the last exit turnstile.

tips.title: Bonjour is Mandatory
tips.description: Entering a store and not saying **Bonjour** is considered extremely rude. Service changes completely if you greet the waiter/waitresse first.

tips.title: Tip (Pourboire)
tips.description: The service (15%) is already included in the bill (**Service Compris**). Leaving a tip is not mandatory like in Brazil or the USA, but leaving a few cents or 1-2 euros is kind if the service was good.

tips.title: Dinner Hours
tips.description: French people dine late, but restaurants have strict opening hours. Lunch is from 12pm to 2pm and dinner from 7:30pm to 10pm. Outside these times, look for places with a **Service Continu** sign.

highlights.info: Serves food all day, without a break in the afternoon.

tips.title: Escalator
tips.description: On the subway and shops: always stay on the right if you are stopped. The left is free for those in a hurry (and they always are).

tips.title: Golden Ring Scam
tips.description: If someone "finds" a gold ring on the floor and offers it to you, ignore it. It's a classic scam to ask for money later. Just say 'Non' and keep walking.

tips.title: Public Bathrooms (Sanisettes)
tips.description: There are free automatic toilets on the streets. Wait for the person to leave and the door to close for the cleaning cycle to finish before entering.

highlights.info: The bathroom sanitizes itself after each use. It takes about 1 min.

tips.title: Chinese Restaurant
tips.description: Come and discover the **13éme** neighborhood, the famous Chinatown in Paris. Look for delicious **Ramens** and **Biang Biang** pasta

highlights.info: A single mass, opened by hand, measuring almost 2 meters.

tips.title: Paris Chinatown
tips.description: Here we have a beautiful Chinatown with lots of giant graffiti murals, so come prepared to walk around and be amazed.

highlights.info: Murals painted on various buildings by artists from around the world

tips.title: Strict Lunch Schedule
tips.description: French people eat lunch between 12pm and 2pm. Many restaurants close the kitchen at 2pm sharp. If you miss the schedule, look for places with a **Service Continu** sign or bakeries (**Boulangeries**).

highlights.info: Serves meals all day long, without a break.

tips.title: Bread at the Restaurant
tips.description: The bread basket (**corbeille de pain**) is generally free and replenished as you wish, as is the water. There is no cover charge paid like in Brazil. Use to wipe the sauce off the plate at the end.

tips.title: Formula Midi Menu
tips.description: At lunch, look for **Formule Midi**. It is a fixed price menu that includes Starter + Main or Main + Dessert (or all three). It's much cheaper than ordering '**à la carte**'.

tips.title: Café Gourmand
tips.description: Undecided dessert? Order a **Café Gourmand**. It is an espresso served with 3 or 4 miniatures of the house's desserts. Perfect for trying a little bit of everything.

tips.title: Steak Tartare
tips.description: A French classic: raw meat (beef) chopped with the tip of a knife and seasoned. If you don't like raw meat, don't order it! It usually comes with fries.

tips.title: Meat Cooking (La Cuisson)
tips.description: The French eat rare meat. If you order 'à point' (**à point**), it will come pink. If you like it well done, ask for **bien cuit**, but the chef may look at you the wrong way.

tips.title: Organized Mess in Bistros
tips.description: Tables in Parisian bistros are tiny and close together. It's normal to hear your neighbor's conversation and even start a conversation. It's part of the city's charm.

tips.title: Waiter is not your friend
tips.description: French service is formal and efficient, not necessarily 'friendly' by Brazilian standards. Don't expect constant smiles. Call by raising your hand and saying '**S'il vous plaît**'.

highlights.info: Please. Essential for calling the waiter.

tips.title: Cheeses after the Dish
tips.description: The cheese board (**Plateau de Fromages**) is served *before* dessert and *after* the main course, or replacing dessert. Never as an aperitif.

tips.title: House Wine (Pichet)
tips.description: No need to order the most expensive bottle. The 25cl or 50cl **Pichet de Vin** (jar of house wine) is usually cheap and decent to accompany lunch.

highlights.info: Carafe of wine, cheaper than a bottle.

tips.title: Croissant is at Breakfast
tips.description: Croissants are typical for breakfast. Many restaurants do not serve croissants as a dessert for lunch or dinner. Buy at **Boulangerie**.

tips.title: Jambon-Beurre
tips.description: The cheapest and most classic lunch in Paris: half a baguette, quality butter and cooked ham. It is sold in any bakery and it is delicious.

tips.title: Happy Hour (L'Afterwork)
tips.description: Many bars have Happy Hour (usually from 5pm to 8pm) with half-price beers (**Pintes**) and cocktails. Look for signs on the sidewalk.

tips.title: Escargots are delicious
tips.description: Don't be disgusted! They taste like butter, garlic and parsley. The texture is similar to a firm mushroom. It's worth trying as a starter.

tips.title: Onion Soup (Soupe à l'Oignon)
tips.description: Comfort in the form of food. Caramelized onion broth, covered with bread and lots of gratin cheese (**Gratinée**). Perfect for winter.

tips.title: Macarons: Pierre Hermé vs Ladurée
tips.description: The eternal fight. **Ladurée** is classic, traditional. **Pierre Hermé** is modern, with exotic flavors (like **Ispahan**: rose, lychee and raspberry). Try both.

tips.title: Street Crepes
tips.description: The best and cheapest snacks. A Nutella or cheese crepe bought from a window in **Montmartre** or **Quartier Latin** saves the day.

tips.title: Angelina's Hot Chocolate
tips.description: At **Angelina** Tea Room, the hot chocolate (**L'Africain**) is so thick you almost have to chew it. An unforgettable caloric bomb.

highlights.info: Famous tea house on Rue de Rivoli.

tips.title: Falafel in the Marais
tips.description: On **Rue des Rosiers**, **L'As du Fallafel** has huge queues for the best falafel sandwich in town. It's street food, cheap and filling.

tips.title: Raclette and Fondue
tips.description: Winter dishes. **Raclette** is melted cheese shaved over potatoes and cold cuts. **Fondue** is a pan of melted cheese. Go to **Le Refuge des Fondus** for a fun experience.

tips.title: Berthillon: The Ice Cream of the Island
tips.description: On **Île Saint-Louis**, the **Berthillon** ice cream parlor is legendary. Try the wild strawberry **sorbet** (**fraise des bois**) or salted caramel.

tips.title: Street Markets (Marchés)
tips.description: Visit a street market (like **Marché Bastille** or Raspail) to buy fresh fruit, cheese and roast chicken (**poulet rôti**) for a picnic.

tips.title: Picnic on the Seine
tips.description: In summer, do as the locals do: Buy wine, cheese and baguette and sit by the **Seine** or **Canal Saint-Martin** to watch the sunset.

tips.title: Reservations are Essential
tips.description: To dine in popular restaurants, booking days in advance is mandatory. Use apps like **TheFork** or the restaurant's own website.

highlights.info: Popular app for reservations and discounts.

tips.title: Oysters (Huîtres)
tips.description: The French love oysters, especially at Christmas. They are served raw, with lemon and shallot vinegar, bread and butter.

tips.title: Foie gras
tips.description: Controversial, but a national delicacy. Fatty duck or goose liver. Generally served in **terrine** with toast and fig jam.

tips.title: Confit de Canard
tips.description: Duck leg cooked slowly in its own fat until falling apart. A classic, safe and delicious dish from southwestern France.

tips.title: Beef Bourguignon
tips.description: Meat cooked in red wine with carrots, onions and mushrooms for hours. The taste of Burgundy in a dish.

tips.title: Galette vs Crêpe
tips.description: In Brittany and Paris: **Galette** is savory, made from buckwheat (dark). **Crêpe** is sweet, made from white wheat. Order a **Galette Complète** (egg, ham, cheese).

tips.title: Dijon mustard
tips.description: French mustard is strong! It will clear your sinuses. It stays on the table to accompany meats, as well as salt and pepper.

tips.title: Typical Breakfast
tips.description: It's light: A coffee, an orange juice and a **viennoiserie** (croissant or **pain au chocolat**). Don't expect eggs and bacon unless you order 'Brunch'.

tips.title: Supermarkets: Monoprix and Franprix
tips.description: **Monoprix** is the 'chic' supermarket with clothes and food. **Franprix** and **Carrefour City** are smaller for quick purchases. Great for buying gastronomic souvenirs.

tips.title: Sauerkraut (Choucroute)
tips.description: Alsatian dish very common in **Brasseries**. Fermented cabbage with various sausages, bacon and potatoes. For those who are very hungry.

tips.title: Kebab in Paris
tips.description: '**Grec**' (Kebab) is young people's favorite fast food. Skewered meat, French fries and white sauce (**sauce blanche**) inside bread. Cheap and sustainable.

tips.title: Profiteroles
tips.description: Carolinas filled with vanilla ice cream and covered in hot chocolate sauce. A dessert that pleases everyone.

tips.title: Tart Tatin
tips.description: The upside down apple pie. The apples are caramelized at the bottom of the pan and the dough goes on top. Served hot with fresh cream (**crème fraîche**).

tips.title: Baba au Rhum
tips.description: A spongy dumpling drenched in rum syrup. Often served with **whipped cream**. Be careful: it contains real alcohol!

tips.title: Don't ask for ketchup
tips.description: Asking for ketchup to be added to a refined dish may offend the chef. Use the sauces that come with the dish. Ketchup is only accepted with french fries.

tips.title: Le Bouillon
tips.description: Historic restaurants (such as **Bouillon Chartier** or **Pigalle**) serving French classics at very low prices in **Belle Époque** salons. Go early to avoid queues.

tips.title: Croque Monsieur
tips.description: The French hot mix, but gratin with **béchamel** and cheese on the outside. If you put a cracked egg on top, it becomes **Croque-Madame**.

tips.title: Mille-Feuille (Yarrow)
tips.description: Three layers of puff pastry sandwiched with pastry cream. Top with powdered sugar or icing. A test of ability to eat without disassembling.

tips.title: Eclair
tips.description: The famous 'bomb'. **choux** dough filled with cream (chocolate, coffee or vanilla) and covered with icing. The salted caramel ones are divine.

tips.title: Lunch in the Garden
tips.description: Buy a salad or sandwich at **Paul** or **Pret a Manger** and eat on the green chairs in the **Tuileries** or Luxembourg Gardens like a true Parisian.

tips.title: Eating with your hands?
tips.description: Bread, yes. Roast chicken and fries, sometimes. Pizza? Fork and knife in most places. Hamburger? Hand, but be careful with the mess.

tips.title: 500 Euro banknotes
tips.description: Many small shops and restaurants do not accept 200 or 500 euro bills. Try using lower notes (10, 20, 50).

tips.title: Fumeurs (Smokers)
tips.description: Smoking is prohibited inside restaurants, but terraces (sidewalk tables) are permitted. If you hate cigarettes, sit inside (**salle**).

tips.title: Tip on Card
tips.description: Card machines in France generally do not have an option to add a tip. If you want to leave, leave euro coins on the table.

tips.title: Eating Late at Night
tips.description: After 10pm, it is difficult to find an open kitchen. Look for '**Au Pied de Cochon**' (open 24 hours a day) or fast food chains if you get hungry in the early hours of the morning.

tips.title: The T+ Ticket
tips.description: The basic metro ticket is valid for metro, bus, tramway and **RER** (**zone 1**). Don't throw it away until it's out of season! Inspection (**controleurs**) is frequent and the fine is high if you do not have a validated ticket.

tips.title: Navigo Découverte
tips.description: Will you stay for a week (Monday to Sunday)? Make the **Navigo Découverte**. It costs ~€30 and gives unlimited access to all areas (including Disney and Airports). Need a 3x4 photo.

tips.title: Escalator: Right!
tips.description: Rule of thumb: Stand to the right. The left is free for those in a hurry. If you block left, you will hear a '**Pardon**!' angry or will be pushed.

tips.title: RER B: CDG Airport
tips.description: **RER** B is the train that connects **Charles de Gaulle** airport to the center. Be careful: there are 'direct' (express) and '**omnibus**' trains (they stop at all). Take the direct to save time and safety.

tips.title: Metro closes at 1am
tips.description: The subway is not 24 hours a day. During the week it closes around 1am, and Fridays/Saturdays at 2am. After that, just taxi, Uber or night bus (**Noctilien**).

tips.title: Citymapper is the best app
tips.description: Forget Google Maps for public transport. Citymapper is much more accurate in Paris, even indicating which carriage to take to exit facing the stairs.

tips.title: Beware of the Manual Door
tips.description: Many old subway lines do not open the door by themselves. You need to lift the silver lever or press the green button when the train stops.

tips.title: Zone 1 vs Zones 1-5
tips.description: Tourist Paris (**Eiffel Tower**, **Louvre**, **Montmartre**) is all **Zone 1**. You only need a special ticket (**Zone 4** or 5) for **Versailles**, Disney or Airports.

tips.title: Velib' (Bicycles)
tips.description: Public bikes are great. The green ones are mechanical, the blue ones are electrical (more expensive). Download the official app to view free stations.

tips.title: Taxi has a fixed price from the Airport
tips.description: From **CDG** to Paris (**Rive Droite**/Gauche) the taxi has a fixed price (approx. €55-€62). Do not accept taxi meters or drivers approaching you in the lobby (they are pirates). Go to the official queue.

tips.title: Walk (Flâner)
tips.description: Paris is small (10km wide). The metro stations are very close (500m). It is often quicker and more beautiful to go on foot than to go underground.

tips.title: Be careful on the crowded subway
tips.description: Line 1 (yellow) passes through the main points and is a frequent target of pickpockets, especially at the **Châtelet** and **Franklin D. Roosevelt** stations.

tips.title: Navigo Easy
tips.description: If you're not going to do it weekly, buy the **Navigo Easy** card (€2) and load it with packages of 10 trips (carnet) digitally. It's cheaper than buying paper tickets.

tips.title: Bus 69: The Cheap Tourist
tips.description: Bus line 69 crosses Paris passing by the Tower, **Invalides**, **Louvre**, **Bastille** and **Père Lachaise**. It's a tourist tour for the price of a common ticket.

tips.title: Roissybus
tips.description: Direct bus from **CDG** Airport to the Ópera region (center). Cheaper than a taxi and more comfortable than the **RER** (no stairs), as long as your hotel is close to the Opera.

tips.title: Orlyval is expensive
tips.description: From **Orly** airport, the **Orlyval** train is fast but has an expensive special fare. **Orlybus** is a cheaper alternative that leaves you at **Denfert-Rochereau** station.

tips.title: Bateaux-Mouches
tips.description: The boat on the **Sine** is not just for tourists. It is the most beautiful transport in the city. The **Batobus** works as a river hop-on hop-off, stopping at the main museums.

tips.title: Strikes (Grèves)
tips.description: Transport in Paris may stop due to strikes. Download the **Bonjour RATP** or Citymapper app to see real-time alerts. Always have a plan B (Uber/Bolt or legs).

tips.title: Uber and G7
tips.description: Uber works well, but taxis (G7) can use bus lanes, which makes them faster in heavy traffic. Download the G7 app.

tips.title: Validate your Navigo
tips.description: Even with the unlimited pass, you must validate the card at the purple turnstile every time you enter the bus or subway. If the inspector catches it without validating it, he will issue a fine.

tips.title: Chatelet-Les Halles Station
tips.description: It is the largest underground station in the world. A labyrinth. Avoid changing lines there if you can, you can walk inside for 15 minutes just to change platforms.

tips.title: Montmartre Funicular
tips.description: To go up to **Sacré-Cœur**, use a regular metro ticket on the Funicular if you don't want to climb the 300 steps on foot. The same ticket is worth it.

tips.title: Scooters (Trottinettes)
tips.description: Rental electric scooters (Lime, etc.) have been banned in Paris in 2023. You won't find them on the streets. Rent a bike.

tips.title: Outputs (Sortie)
tips.description: Large stations have several numbered exits. Look on the platform map which '**Sortie**' is closest to your destination. Going down the wrong street can cost you 10 minutes of walking.

tips.title: Subway 6: The View
tips.description: Line 6 is partially aerial. Between the **Bir-Hakeim** and **Passy** stations, it crosses the **Seine** with a spectacular view of the **Eiffel Tower**. Prepare the camera.

tips.title: Restrooms at Stations
tips.description: Rare and generally paid or closed. Don't count on bathrooms in the subway. Use it before leaving the museum/restaurant or look for people on the street.

tips.title: Line 14: The Fastest
tips.description: Automatic (without driver), modern and fast. Cross the city from north to south in minutes. Great for escaping traffic or slower lines.

tips.title: Give way
tips.description: Seats close to the doors are priority ('**Priorité**'). Get up immediately if an elderly person, pregnant woman or person with a disability enters. It's law and education.

tips.title: Anti-Fraud Gates
tips.description: Some **RER** exits require a ticket to open the gate. Never throw the ticket away until you are on the street. On the subway, you usually just push the exit gate.

tips.title: Is Paris Visit worth it?
tips.description: Generally not. The **Navigo Découverte** or **Navigo Easy** are usually cheaper than the '**Paris Visit**' tourist pass, unless you want discounts on attractions (which are few).

tips.title: Train to Versailles
tips.description: Take the **RER** C towards **Versailles** **Château** **Rive Gauche**. Caution: **RER** C forks. Look on the screens to see if the train is going to that final destination.

tips.title: Eurostar
tips.description: The train to London leaves from **Gare du Nord**. Check-in requires advance notice (90min) due to immigration (Brexit). Don't arrive at the last minute like on a regular train.

tips.title: Bolt and FreeNow
tips.description: Alternatives to Uber. Download the Bolt and FreeNow (formerly Kapten) apps to compare prices. Sometimes they have aggressive promotions.

tips.title: Autolib (Electric Cars)
tips.description: The old electric car system is over, but there are 'car sharing' services like **Mobilib'**. However, driving in Paris is stressful. Avoid.

tips.title: Bus Lane
tips.description: If you are cycling, you can use most (shared) bus lanes. But be careful with real taxi drivers and buses, they are aggressive.

tips.title: Pedestrian Signals
tips.description: The 'little red doll' is merely suggestive for Parisians, who will cross if there is no car coming. But be careful: fines are rare, but run overs are not.

tips.title: Gare de Lyon vs Gare du Nord
tips.description: Paris has several train stations (Gares), not one central one. Check the ticket: **Gare de Lyon** (south/southeast), **Gare du Nord** (north/London), **Montparnasse** (west), etc.

tips.title: Luggage on the Metro
tips.description: Old stations have many stairs and few escalators/elevators. If you have heavy bags, choose a taxi or bus to avoid carrying weight on the steps.

tips.title: Peak Time (Heure de Pointe)
tips.description: Avoid the metro (especially Line 1 and 13) and **RER** A between 8am-9:30am and 5:30pm-7pm. You will be sardines in a can.

tips.title: Security Controls
tips.description: In large train stations, there may be random luggage searches (**Vigipirate Plan**). Collaborate with security.

tips.title: Digital tickets (Android/iOS)
tips.description: You can buy T+ tickets directly via your cell phone (Samsung/Android has better support, iPhone has started to do so). The cell phone becomes the ticket at the turnstile (NFC).

tips.title: Disney Paris (RER A)
tips.description: For Disney, take the **RER** towards **Marne-la-Vallée** – **Chessy**. The final station is at the parks gate. **Zone 5** (expensive ticket).

tips.title: Offline Navigation Apps
tips.description: Download the Paris map from Google Maps for offline use, but Citymapper needs data for actual times.

tips.title: Bike Lanes (Pistes Cyclables)
tips.description: Paris is full of new cycle paths (**Rue de Rivoli** looks like a bike highway). Be careful when walking so as not to invade the cyclists' lane.

tips.title: Arts et Métiers Station
tips.description: The most beautiful metro station (Line 11). It looks like a copper submarine, inspired by Jules Verne. It's worth the visit just for the design.

tips.title: Voi, Lime and Dott (Bikes)
tips.description: In addition to the Velib, there are 'dockless' electric bikes from these brands. They are more expensive than the Velib, but easier to find and park.

tips.title: The 'Bonjour' Rule
tips.description: When entering any store or establishment, say '**Bonjour**' (or '**Bonsoir**') loud and clear. Ignoring this is considered rude and you will be treated coldly. It's the magic key to sympathy.

tips.title: Free Museums on the 1st Sunday
tips.description: Many national museums (such as **Orsay**, **Orangerie**, **Pompidou**) are free on the first Sunday of the month. **Louvre** too, but only in low season and reservations are mandatory.

tips.title: Mona Lisa: Go Early or Late
tips.description: The Mona Lisa room in the **Louvre** is chaos. Go as soon as the museum opens (9am) or at night (Fridays until 9:45pm) to see it with less pushing and shoving.

tips.title: Carnavalet Museum
tips.description: The Paris history museum. It's in **Marais**, it's free (the permanent collection) and not very crowded. Perfect for understanding the evolution of the city.

tips.title: Tipping is not mandatory
tips.description: Reinforcing the culture: waiters receive a fixed salary. Don't feel pressured to give 20% like in the US. Round the bill if you want.

tips.title: Don't speak loudly
tips.description: French people speak softly in restaurants and on transport. Brazilians tend to speak loudly. Try lowering the volume so you don't attract dirty looks.

tips.title: Paris Museum Pass
tips.description: If you plan to go to a lot of museums in 2 or 4 days, the PMP makes up for it financially and (sometimes) skips the line. Includes **Louvre**, **Arc de Triomphe**, **Versailles**, etc.

tips.title: Shakespeare and Company Bookstore
tips.description: Historic English bookstore in front of **Notre-Dame**. Attended by Hemingway. Taking photos inside is prohibited, respect the rules.

tips.title: Heritage Days
tips.description: In September (**Journées du Patrimoine**), government buildings closed to the public (such as the Élysée Palace or the Senate) open their doors free of charge. Long lines, but worth it.

tips.title: Père Lachaise Cemetery
tips.description: It's not morbid, it's an open-air museum park. See the graves of Jim Morrison, Oscar Wilde, Edith Piaf and Chopin. Map at the entrance helps.

tips.title: Opera Garnier
tips.description: The 'Phantom of the Opera' takes place here. The interior is more impressive than **Versailles** for many. Visit during the day or watch a ballet.

tips.title: Saint-Chapelle: Stained Glass
tips.description: Hidden in the Palace of Justice, it has the most beautiful stained glass windows in the world. Go on a sunny day to see the light explode with color inside.

tips.title: Moulin Rouge
tips.description: Tourist? Yes. Expensive? Yes. But it's history. The can-can show is professional and the atmosphere is iconic. Book months in advance.

tips.title: Bouquinistes
tips.description: Sellers of books and old posters in the green boxes on the banks of the **Seine**. UNESCO Heritage Site. Great for buying cheap vintage posters.

tips.title: Nuit Blanche
tips.description: Annual event (October or June) where art takes over the city all night long. Installations, shows and museums open early in the morning for free.

tips.title: Notre-Dame Cathedral
tips.description: Reopening after the fire. The exterior has already been restored. The **Ground Zero** of France's roads is on the ground in the square in front.

tips.title: Orangery Museum
tips.description: Home to Monet's giant '**Nymphéas**'. Two oval rooms designed by the painter himself to display the works. Zen and unmissable.

tips.title: English in Paris
tips.description: Parisians, especially young people, speak English well. The myth that they 'don't respond' comes from those who don't say '**Bonjour**' first. Start in French, switch later.

tips.title: Pardon and Excusez-moi
tips.description: Did you bump into someone? Say '**Pardon**'. Do you want to ask for permission or information? '**Excusez-moi**'. Politeness is social currency.

tips.title: Catacombs: Book Before
tips.description: The underground ossuary. The queue is kilometers long. Without a ticket purchased online with a pre-booked time, you practically won't get in. Claustrophobic, avoid.

tips.title: Center Pompidou
tips.description: Modern and contemporary art. The architecture of colored tubes on the outside is controversial. The view from the top floor is incredible.

tips.title: Rodin Museum
tips.description: Where is 'The Thinker'. The sculpture garden is wonderful to stroll through. It is close to the **Invalides**.

tips.title: Don't touch the works
tips.description: It seems obvious, but alarms go off if you get too close. Keep a respectful distance in museums.

tips.title: Church Attire
tips.description: Covered shoulders are not strictly required as in Italy, but avoid very short shorts or plunging necklines when visiting active churches.

tips.title: Tokyo Palace
tips.description: 'Cool' contemporary art center, open until midnight. Great for seeing weird exhibits and drinking in the trendy bar.

tips.title: Le Marais on Sunday
tips.description: While Paris sleeps on Sunday, the **Marais** is buzzing. Stores open, streets full. The center of Jewish and LGBTQ+ life.

tips.title: Petit Palais
tips.description: City Museum of Fine Arts. Free, beautiful and has an internal garden with a cafe that is an oasis of peace near the **Champs-Élysées**.

tips.title: Napoleon's Bicentenary
tips.description: His tomb is in the Dôme des **Invalides**. It's grand. Army Museum (Musée de l'Armée) in the same complex is excellent for war history.

tips.title: Cinema in Paris
tips.description: Paris has the highest density of cinemas in the world. Go to an art cinema in the **Quartier Latin** or the Grand Rex (largest in Europe).

tips.title: Louis Vuitton Foundation
tips.description: Frank Gehry's futuristic building in the **Bois de Boulogne**. Worth it for the architecture and important temporary exhibitions (like Basquiat/Warhol).

tips.title: Fête de la Musique
tips.description: June 21st. Amateur and professional musicians take over every corner of Paris. The city becomes a free open-air party.

tips.title: Fashion and Style
tips.description: You don't need to wear a beret and stripes (tourist cliché). The Parisian style is discreet, neutral colors, 'effortlessly chic'. White sneakers are the official footwear.

tips.title: Galeries Lafayette (Dome)
tips.description: Come in, even if just to look at the ceiling. The stained glass dome is stunning. At Christmas, the giant suspended tree is a tourist attraction.

tips.title: Do 'Bise'
tips.description: When greeting friends, French people give two kisses (bise). In Paris, start on the right. But as a tourist, shaking hands is safe.

tips.title: Free Toilet in Museums
tips.description: Golden tip: You can enter the hall of many museums (such as the **Petit Palais**) just to use the clean and free bathroom without paying an entrance fee.

tips.title: Conciergerie
tips.description: Where Marie Antoinette was imprisoned before the guillotine. Today it uses augmented reality (HistoPad) to show what it was like during the Revolution. Very immersive.

tips.title: Arc de Triomphe: View
tips.description: For many, the best view of Paris, because it includes the **Eiffel Tower**. There is an elevator, but only for the disabled/elderly, prepare your legs.

tips.title: Crémieux Street
tips.description: Colorful street famous on Instagram. Residents hate the noise. If so, be silent and respectful. Do not climb the steps of houses.

tips.title: Bracelet Scam (Sacré-Cœur)
tips.description: On the steps of **Montmartre**, men will try to tie a bracelet on your arm 'in friendship' and then aggressively demand payment. Keep your arms crossed or in your pockets and ignore them.

tips.title: False Undersigned
tips.description: Young people (usually girls) with clipboards asking for signatures to 'help deaf-mutes'. It's a distraction to steal your wallet or ask for a forced donation. Don't sign.

tips.title: Emergency Number: 112
tips.description: The universal emergency number in Europe is 112 (police, ambulance, fire). It works from any cell phone, even locked.

tips.title: Wallet in Front Pocket
tips.description: Wallet and cell phone in the back pocket of your pants are gifts for pickpockets. Use front pockets, pockets or cross-body zipper bags.

tips.title: Don't Leave Your Cell Phone on the Table
tips.description: In cafes with tables on the sidewalk, never leave your cell phone on the table. Thieves run past or place a paper on top to distract and take the device.

tips.title: Areas to Avoid at Night
tips.description: The area north of **Gare du Nord** and **Gare de l'Est** (Barbès, La Chapelle) can be intimidating and unsafe late at night. Avoid staying or walking alone there in the early hours of the morning.

tips.title: Cups Game Scam
tips.description: Avoid crowds around street gambling (with nutshells or glasses). It's all a setup. Whoever wins is an accomplice, you will only lose money.

tips.title: Fake Police Officers
tips.description: If someone undercover asks to see your wallet/money to 'check for fake bills', it's a scam. Real cops never ask to see your money.

tips.title: Pharmacies on Duty
tips.description: Pharmacies have a neon green cross. If it is closed at night, look on the door for the address of the nearest 'Pharmacie de Garde' (on duty).

tips.title: Tap Water is Safe and Good
tips.description: The water in Paris is of high quality. You can drink from the hotel tap or public fountains (Wallace) on the street without fear. Save money.

tips.title: Tuk-Tuk Scam
tips.description: Tuk-tuks near the **Eiffel Tower** charge exorbitant prices. Agree the price CLEARLY before entering, or prefer to walk/subway.

tips.title: Be careful on RER B
tips.description: On the train from the airport, keep your bags close to you. Thieves rush into stops before Paris and pull suitcases close to the door before it closes.

tips.title: Manifestations (Manif)
tips.description: Protests are common in Paris. Generally peaceful, but may have tear gas. If you see a police crowd, change your route. Saturdays are traditional protest days.

tips.title: Mandatory Travel Insurance
tips.description: To enter Europe (Schengen), it is mandatory to have travel insurance with coverage of 30 thousand euros. Immigration may ask to see the policy.

tips.title: 'Fura-Fila' Ticket Scam
tips.description: Do not buy tickets from scalpers on the street for the **Louvre** or **Eiffel Tower**. They are almost always fake or used. Buy only on official websites or ticket offices.

tips.title: Canicule (Heat wave)
tips.description: In summer, Paris can reach 40°C. Many older hotels and subways DO NOT have air conditioning. Check this when booking if you are traveling in August.

tips.title: Fire Extinguishers
tips.description: Paris firefighters (Sapeurs-Pompiers) are military personnel. In case of fire or serious medical accident, call 18.

tips.title: Police (17)
tips.description: To call the police in an emergency (robbery, assault), the direct number in France is 17.

tips.title: Samu (15)
tips.description: For urgent medical emergencies (heart attack, etc.), the number is 15. They send a doctor or ambulance.

tips.title: Fake Cigarettes
tips.description: Street vendors offering cheap 'Marlboro' (Vendeurs a la sauvette). It is fake tobacco of poor quality and dangerous. Don't buy.

tips.title: Don't Feed the Pigeons
tips.description: It is prohibited to feed pigeons in Paris. There are fines for this, as they are considered health pests.

tips.title: Rats in Parks
tips.description: Yes, Paris has rats. You can see them in parks at night or on subway tracks. They usually run away from humans, don't panic.

tips.title: Terrorism (Vigipirate)
tips.description: France has a constant terrorism alert. It is normal to see armed soldiers patrolling tourist attractions. Feel safe, not threatened.

tips.title: Bags on the Floor
tips.description: In fancy restaurants or bistros, avoid placing your bag on the floor where someone could pull it from behind your chair. Keep it on your lap or use hooks if available.

tips.title: Fake Taxi at the Airport
tips.description: Refuse anyone who approaches you in the lobby saying 'Taxi?'. Follow the 'Taxis' signs to the official outside queue. The scam can cost twice the price.

tips.title: Aggressive Cyclists
tips.description: When crossing the street, also look for cycle paths. Parisian cyclists go fast and don't always stop at red lights.

tips.title: Flower Coup
tips.description: Someone offers you a rose 'as a gift'. If you catch them, they will demand money and make a scene. Don't take anything from strangers.

tips.title: American Hospital
tips.description: If you need a doctor who speaks English (and has good insurance, as it is expensive), the American Hospital of Paris in Neuilly-sur-Seine is a reference.

tips.title: Lost your Passport?
tips.description: Brazilian Consulate in Paris. Always have a physical and digital copy of your passport stored separately to facilitate emergency issuance.

tips.title: Bath in Chafariz
tips.description: It is prohibited to enter fountains and fountains (such as Trocadero), even in hot weather. The police can fine you.

tips.title: Nocturnal Noises
tips.description: Paris is noisy. If you are a light sleeper, bring ear plugs, as sirens and garbage trucks are common in the early hours of the morning.

tips.title: Padlocks on the Bridge
tips.description: Do not place padlocks on bridges (such as Pont des Arts). They weigh down and destroy the structure. The city removes it regularly.

tips.title: Defibrillators (AED)
tips.description: There are many automatic external defibrillators in stations and public buildings. Look for the green 'DAE' sign.

tips.title: Photo Scam
tips.description: Someone offers to take a photo of you and your group with their camera, and runs off with it. Ask other tourists, not overly helpful 'locals'.

tips.title: Crowded Subway and Backpack
tips.description: Take your backpack off your back on the crowded subway. In addition to disturbing others, on your back you won't feel it if they open the zipper.

tips.title: Luxembourg Garden
tips.description: Parisians' favorite garden. Great for running, reading a book on the green metal chairs or watching the little boats on the lake. It is close to the Pantheon.

tips.title: Tickets Covers
tips.description: 19th century shopping arcades with glass ceilings. Perfect for rainy days. Visit Galerie Vivienne (chic) ​​or Passage des Panoramas (foodie).

tips.title: Montmartre beyond the Sacré-Cœur
tips.description: Escape the crowd in front of the church. Explore Rue des Abbesses and Place Dalida. Visit the **Montmartre** vineyard (Clos **Montmartre**), the only one within Paris.

tips.title: Coulee Verte
tips.description: A hanging garden built on old train tracks. It was the inspiration for the High Line in NY. It starts near the **Bastille** and is a green and peaceful walk.

tips.title: Montparnasse Tower
tips.description: They say it has the best view of Paris because it's the only place where you don't see the ugly **Montparnasse Tower**. The view from the terrace on the 56th floor is spectacular.

tips.title: Canal Saint-Martin
tips.description: Hipster area of ​​Paris. Great for picnics, playing pétanque and drinking beer at the water's edge. Scene from the film Amélie Poulain (can you find the stones she threw?).

tips.title: Île de la Cité vs Île Saint-Louis
tips.description: The Cité has **Notre-Dame** and tourists. Saint-Louis is residential, calm, with **Berthillon** ice creams and 17th century mansions. Cross the bridge and feel the difference.

tips.title: Rue Crémieux (Respect)
tips.description: The most colorful street in Paris. It's beautiful, but residential. Don't make noise, don't climb the stairs of houses and don't block residents' passage. Be discreet.

tips.title: Le Marias (Neighborhood)
tips.description: Historic neighborhood that was not destroyed by Haussmann. Narrow medieval streets, mansions (Hôtels Particuliers), design shops and the best gay scene in the city.

tips.title: Parc des Buttes-Chaumont
tips.description: The steepest and most dramatic park. It has a cave, waterfall, suspension bridge and a temple on top of a cliff. Few tourists, many locals.

tips.title: Is the Champs-Élysées tourist-friendly?
tips.description: A little. It's crowded, expensive and has many international chain stores. The **Arc de Triomphe** is worth seeing, but for authentic shopping, prefer **Marais** or Saint-Germain.

tips.title: Latin Quarter
tips.description: The student district (Sorbonne). Old streets, bookstores, art cinemas and lots of cheap bars on Rue Mouffetard. Intellectual and bohemian atmosphere.

tips.title: Rue de Rivoli
tips.description: Famous for its souvenir shops and fast fashion. Walk through it under the arcades. The cycle path here is very busy.

tips.title: Place des Vosges
tips.description: The oldest and most symmetrical square in Paris, in the **Marais**. Sit on the grass on sunny days. Victor Hugo lived here (his house is a free museum).

tips.title: Palais Royal
tips.description: Close to the **Louvre**, but quiet. The courtyard has Buren's striped columns (Colonnes de Buren) great for photos, and a chic fenced garden.

tips.title: Alexandre III Bridge
tips.description: The most extravagant and golden bridge. Connects the **Invalides** to the **Grand Palais**. The sunset here is a guaranteed postcard.

tips.title: La Defense
tips.description: The modern Paris of skyscrapers. It's worth a visit to see the **Grande Arche** (giant cube aligned with the **Arc de Triomphe**) and the 4 Temps shopping mall.

tips.title: Tuileries Garden
tips.description: Between the **Louvre** and **Concorde**. Dusty in summer, but classic. Sit around the fountains and watch the Ferris wheel in the background.

tips.title: Grande Mosquée of Paris
tips.description: A Moorish oasis in the Latin Quarter. It has a beautiful courtyard, a tea room with delicious Arabic sweets and a Turkish bath (Hammam).

tips.title: Rue Montorgueil
tips.description: Pedestrian street full of cheese shops, fishmongers, bakeries and cafes. One of the most charming and lively market streets in the center (Les Halles).

tips.title: Parc de la Villette
tips.description: Giant cultural park. There's the **Cité des Sciences**, the Philharmonie and open-air cinema in the summer. Far from the classic center.

tips.title: Cherry Blossoms
tips.description: In April, Paris turns pink. The best places to see cherry blossoms (Sakura) are the Jardin des Plantes and around **Notre-Dame**.

tips.title: Flea Market (Saint-Ouen)
tips.description: The largest antiques market in the world. It is in the north (Porte de Clignancourt). It has everything from Louis XV furniture to cheap vintage clothes.

tips.title: Bibliothèque Nationale (Richelieu)
tips.description: The oval reading room (**Salle** Ovale) is jaw-dropping. Recently opened to the public for visits. A temple of books.

tips.title: Arenes de Lutèce
tips.description: Ruins of a Roman amphitheater hidden in a park in the **Quartier Latin**. Paris has Roman history! Great for kids to play ball.

tips.title: Rue Denoyez (Street Art)
tips.description: In **Belleville**, a legal street for graffiti. The art changes every week. The region is vibrant and multicultural.

tips.title: Printemps Haussmann
tips.description: Competitor of **Galeries Lafayette**. The terrace on the 9th floor is free and has an incredible 360º view of Paris, better than the one next door.

tips.title: Saint-Germain-des-Prés
tips.description: The chic and intellectual neighborhood. Famous cafes (Les Deux Magots, Café de Flore), art galleries and luxury stores. Classic Parisian atmosphere.

tips.title: Hotel de Ville
tips.description: Paris City Hall. The square in front has seasonal events: skating rink in winter, big screens at the Olympics, ephemeral garden in summer.

tips.title: Bercy Village
tips.description: Former wine warehouses transformed into an open-air shopping mall and restaurants. Close to the **Bercy** park and the Cinematheque.

tips.title: Pont Neuf
tips.description: Despite the name 'New Bridge', it is the oldest bridge in Paris. It has stone 'balconies' that are great for sitting and relaxing over the river.

tips.title: Place de la Concorde
tips.description: Where the guillotine was in the Revolution. Today there is the Luxor Obelisk (a gift from Egypt) and beautiful fountains. Be careful when crossing, the traffic is crazy.

tips.title: Samaritaine
tips.description: Luxury department store recently reopened. The **Art Nouveau** and Art Deco architecture is spectacular. Expensive to buy, free to admire.

tips.title: Bois de Boulogne
tips.description: The green lung of the west. It has lakes with boats, a botanical garden and the Louis Vuitton Foundation. Avoid going at night (prostitution).

tips.title: Bois de Vincennes
tips.description: The green lung of the east. It has a real medieval castle (**Château** de Vincennes) and a modern zoo.

tips.title: Citypharma Pharmacy
tips.description: The cosmetics paradise in Saint-Germain. Unbeatable prices for brands like La Roche-Posay, Vichy and Bioderma. Go early, it's an anthill.

tips.title: Monet's Garden (Giverny)
tips.description: Classic round trip. Take the train from **Gare Saint-Lazare** to Vernon. Monet's house and gardens are magical in spring. Book tickets in advance.

tips.title: Fontainebleau Castle
tips.description: Alternative to **Versailles**. Less crowded, equally grand (it was Napoleon's house) and has an incredible forest around it for rock climbing.

tips.title: Disneyland Paris: 1 or 2 parks?
tips.description: If you only have one day, focus on Disneyland Park (the main one). Walt Disney Studios is smaller, but has Marvel and Ratatouille attractions.

tips.title: Pierre Hermé Macaron: Mogador
tips.description: Signature flavor: Milk chocolate and passion fruit. It's an explosion of flavor. There are kiosks at **Galeries Lafayette** and **Champs-Élysées**.

tips.title: Tea at the Mosque
tips.description: The Grand Mosque in Paris serves a wonderful sweet mint tea for 2 euros. Relaxing atmosphere with birds flying between the tables.

tips.title: Department Stores on Sunday
tips.description: **Galeries Lafayette** and **Printemps** are open on Sundays (which is rare for large stores in Paris). The **BHV** in **Marais** too.

tips.title: Tax Free (Détaxe)
tips.description: Did you spend more than €100 in the same store? Ask for the Detaxe form. You recover ~12% of the value at the airport. Have your passport on hand at the store.

tips.title: Type E socket
tips.description: The French outlet has two round prongs and a ground prong protruding from the wall. Bring a universal adapter, the Brazilian 3-pin standard does not fit.

tips.title: Voltage 220V
tips.description: Be careful with 110V dryers and straighteners. They will burn. France is 220V.

tips.title: Cellular Chip (SIM Card)
tips.description: Buy a prepaid chip from Free Mobile (automatic machines in stores) or Orange Holiday. Roaming in Brazil is very expensive.

tips.title: Free Wi-Fi
tips.description: Most public parks have free city hall Wi-Fi ('Paris Wi-Fi'). It's slow, but saves in emergencies.

tips.title: Provins: Medieval City
tips.description: UNESCO heritage site, medieval walled city accessible with the **Navigo** card (**Zone 5**). There are eagle shows and knight tournaments.

tips.title: Auvers-sur-Oise (Van Gogh)
tips.description: The city where Van Gogh lived his last days and is buried. Visit his room at the Ravoux pension. Exciting.

tips.title: Boulangerie 2024
tips.description: Look for the 'Meilleure Baguette de Paris' stamp in the window. The winning bakery supplies bread to the president that year.

tips.title: Comté cheese
tips.description: The French's favorite cheese. Hard, fruity, raw milk. Ask for 'Comté 18 mois' (cured 18 months) for more flavor.

tips.title: Salted Butter (Demi-sel)
tips.description: In France, prefer 'Beurre Demi-sel' (half salt) with salt crystals. Unsalted butter (Doux) is too dull to spread on bread.

tips.title: Honey Vinegar
tips.description: Cheap souvenir: Honey vinegar or cassis mustard, found in fine supermarkets like La Grande Épicerie.

tips.title: La Grande Épicerie
tips.description: **Bon Marché**'s luxury supermarket. It is a gastronomy museum. Great for shopping for fancy edible gifts.

tips.title: Rue Cler
tips.description: A pedestrian market street near the **Eiffel Tower**. Very charming, full of delights, but prices are a bit 'tourist-friendly'.

tips.title: Cluny Museum
tips.description: National Museum of the Middle Ages. It has the famous 'Lady and the Unicorn' tapestries. Reopened renovated and accessible.

tips.title: Sainte-Chapelle: Concert
tips.description: Watch a classical music concert (Vivaldi/Bach) inside the **Sainte-Chapelle** in the evening. Unforgettable acoustics and visuals.

tips.title: Pont Alexandre III at night
tips.description: Lit by **Art Nouveau** streetlights, it's magical. You can see the **Eiffel Tower** blinking (every full hour, for 5 minutes) from there.

tips.title: Tip for Taxi Driver
tips.description: Round the amount. If you gave €18.50, leave €20. Not required, but appreciated.

tips.title: Children's Subway
tips.description: Children under 4 years old are free. From 4 to 10 pay half fare (Carnet réduit) on single tickets.

tips.title: Paris Plages
tips.description: In summer, the banks of the **Seine** become a 'beach' with sand, sun loungers and umbrellas. Free and fun.

tips.title: Canal de l'Ourcq
tips.description: Continuation of the **Canal Saint-Martin**, further north. It has free swimming pools on the canal in summer and self-service electric boats (Marin D'Eau Douce).

tips.title: Parc Monceau
tips.description: The most aristocratic park. Surrounded by golden mansions. It has a pyramid, Roman colonnade and statues. Chiquérrimo.

tips.title: Jacquemart-André Museum
tips.description: A private 19th century mansion, kept exactly as it was. The tea room is one of the most beautiful in Paris. (Check if it has reopened after renovation).

tips.title: Cartier Foundation
tips.description: Jean Nouvel's glass building with wild garden. Top-notch contemporary art. On Boulevard Raspail.

tips.title: Cinémathèque Française
tips.description: Cinema museum, designed by Frank Gehry. For cinephiles. It is in **Bercy** Park.

tips.title: Le Bon Marché
tips.description: The oldest and most elegant department store. Less touristy than Lafayette, frequented by the local elite.

tips.title: Rue de Charonne
tips.description: In the 11th arrondissement. Full of independent designer boutiques and cool bistros. Off the tourist radar.

tips.title: Flower Market
tips.description: On **Île de la Cité**, Place Louis Lépine. A historic flower and bird market (birds only on Sundays, but this is changing).

tips.title: Place Dalida
tips.description: The bust of the singer Dalida in **Montmartre** has her breasts polished from touching them so much (good luck?). The view of Rue Abreuvoir from there is beautiful.

tips.title: Montmartre vineyard
tips.description: Yes, they make wine in Paris. The harvest festival (Fête des Vendanges) in October is a huge event with parades and fireworks.

tips.title: Poilâne Bakery
tips.description: Famous for its naturally fermented bread (miche) with a P drawn on it. Expensive, but it lasts a week fresh.

tips.title: Walk on the Grass
tips.description: Many lawns in Paris are 'interdits' (forbidden). Look for the 'Pelouse autorisée' sign before extending the yoke.

tips.title: Bicycles on the Metro
tips.description: You are only allowed to take a bike on the Metro (Line 1) on Sundays. On **RER** it is permitted outside of peak hours. When in doubt, don't take it.

tips.title: Navette Fluviale (Vogueo)
tips.description: There was a river public transport project, but today the **Batobus** is the closest thing. Not worth a subway ticket.

tips.title: Abbesses Station
tips.description: It has the deepest spiral staircase in Paris. If you're not physically fit, take the giant elevator. Seriously, there are a lot of steps.
